title: How to Clean a Chainsaw

methods.name: Cleaning the Chain and Guide Bar

steps.headline: Put your chainsaw in a secure position on a stable workbench.
steps.description: Place the saw with the base flat against the table and ensure that the chain is not touching anything. You want the chainsaw to move as little as possible when working on it. If you are cleaning an electric chainsaw be sure to disconnect it from any power source first.

steps.headline: Remove the chain from the guide bar and clean out the bar groove.
steps.description: Adjust the knob that controls the slack of the chain to loosen it until you can easily slide it off of the guide bar. Set the chain aside and clean out debris from the guide bar. You can clean the guide bar groove out with a special guide bar groove cleaner and compressed air for best results.

steps.headline: Soak the chain in an ammonia and water solution for 10-20 minutes.
steps.description: After soaking, clean the chain with a bristle brush until you have removed all dirt and grease. To make a cleaning solution, combine 1 gallon of water and 1 cup of household ammonia in a plastic bucket. When working with ammonia make sure to work in a well-ventilated area, and avoid contact with your skin or eyes. It is best to use gloves and eye protection to be safe. Never mix ammonia with chlorine bleach as this produces a toxic gas.

steps.headline: Rinse the chain well with clean water and dry it off.
steps.description: Dry as much off with a clean towel or rag as you can. Hang the chain up to air-dry completely before you lubricate it. Depending on the heat and humidity where you live, air drying could take up to several hours. To dry your chain quicker, you can use compressed air to blast any remaining water off.

steps.headline: Lubricate the chain in chainsaw oil and reattach it to the guide bar.
steps.description: Dip the chain in the oil and hang it up for a few minutes to let excess oil drip off before attaching it to the guide bar. Slide the chain back onto the bar and adjust the knob to tighten it around the guide bar. Put an old rag or some newspapers under the chain while it is hanging to catch any oil drips. Keeping your chainsaw chain and bar lubricated is important to minimize wear and tear on your chain and extend the life of your chainsaw.

methods.name: Unclogging the Carburetor and Air Filter

steps.headline: Look at the carburetor to see if there is any residue clogging it up.
steps.description: If you see gummy buildup then the carburetor needs to be cleaned. Spray the carburetor with compressed air to clean out any residue buildup. Buildup of dirt and old oil will clog the carburetor and block fuel flow to the engine, so it is important to keep it clean to avoid difficulties starting your chainsaw.

steps.headline: Remove the needle valves, diaphragm, and cover plate from the chainsaw.
steps.description: Consult the owner’s manual for your saw if you have difficulties identifying or removing any of these parts. If you are still unsure about how to disassemble your saw, take it to a local dealer for assistance.

steps.headline: Soak the needle valves, diaphragm, and cover plate in a cleaning solution.
steps.description: Let all the parts soak for 10-20 minutes. After they have soaked, thoroughly scrub each part with a bristle brush to remove debris. You can use a cleaning solution of 1 cup of household ammonia mixed with 1 gallon of water in a plastic container. Make sure to work in a well-ventilated area when working with ammonia. Don’t let ammonia get on your skin or in your eyes, use gloves and eye protection to avoid accidents. Never mix ammonia with chlorine bleach or you will create a harmful gas.

steps.headline: Rinse and dry the carburetor parts with clean, cool water and reattach them.
steps.description: Dry the parts with a microfiber towel first and then blast off any remaining water with compressed air. Make sure the parts are completely dry before you reassemble them. Attaching parts when they are still wet can result in rust and damage to your saw.

steps.headline: Remove the air filter and wash it with warm soapy water.
steps.description: If it is particularly dirty, you can soak it in soapy water and then scrub it with a gentle brush. If you are unable to get it completely clean you should replace the filter. You should regularly check your air filter and clean it as needed to avoid problems like excessive fuel consumption and extreme wear on engine parts. Never use compressed air to clean the air filter as you could blast a hole in it and damage it permanently. You can find replacement chainsaw filters at your local hardware department store or chainsaw dealer.

text: Cleaning the Chain and Guide Bar Put your chainsaw in a secure position on a stable workbench. Place the saw with the base flat against the table and ensure that the chain is not touching anything. You want the chainsaw to move as little as possible when working on it. If you are cleaning an electric chainsaw be sure to disconnect it from any power source first. Remove the chain from the guide bar and clean out the bar groove. Adjust the knob that controls the slack of the chain to loosen it until you can easily slide it off of the guide bar. Set the chain aside and clean out debris from the guide bar. You can clean the guide bar groove out with a special guide bar groove cleaner and compressed air for best results. Soak the chain in an ammonia and water solution for 10-20 minutes. After soaking, clean the chain with a bristle brush until you have removed all dirt and grease. To make a cleaning solution, combine 1 gallon of water and 1 cup of household ammonia in a plastic bucket. When working with ammonia make sure to work in a well-ventilated area, and avoid contact with your skin or eyes. It is best to use gloves and eye protection to be safe. Never mix ammonia with chlorine bleach as this produces a toxic gas. Rinse the chain well with clean water and dry it off. Dry as much off with a clean towel or rag as you can. Hang the chain up to air-dry completely before you lubricate it. Depending on the heat and humidity where you live, air drying could take up to several hours. To dry your chain quicker, you can use compressed air to blast any remaining water off. Lubricate the chain in chainsaw oil and reattach it to the guide bar. Dip the chain in the oil and hang it up for a few minutes to let excess oil drip off before attaching it to the guide bar. Slide the chain back onto the bar and adjust the knob to tighten it around the guide bar. Put an old rag or some newspapers under the chain while it is hanging to catch any oil drips. Keeping your chainsaw chain and bar lubricated is important to minimize wear and tear on your chain and extend the life of your chainsaw. Unclogging the Carburetor and Air Filter Look at the carburetor to see if there is any residue clogging it up. If you see gummy buildup then the carburetor needs to be cleaned. Spray the carburetor with compressed air to clean out any residue buildup. Buildup of dirt and old oil will clog the carburetor and block fuel flow to the engine, so it is important to keep it clean to avoid difficulties starting your chainsaw. Remove the needle valves, diaphragm, and cover plate from the chainsaw. Consult the owner’s manual for your saw if you have difficulties identifying or removing any of these parts. If you are still unsure about how to disassemble your saw, take it to a local dealer for assistance. Soak the needle valves, diaphragm, and cover plate in a cleaning solution. Let all the parts soak for 10-20 minutes. After they have soaked, thoroughly scrub each part with a bristle brush to remove debris. You can use a cleaning solution of 1 cup of household ammonia mixed with 1 gallon of water in a plastic container. Make sure to work in a well-ventilated area when working with ammonia. Don’t let ammonia get on your skin or in your eyes, use gloves and eye protection to avoid accidents. Never mix ammonia with chlorine bleach or you will create a harmful gas. Rinse and dry the carburetor parts with clean, cool water and reattach them. Dry the parts with a microfiber towel first and then blast off any remaining water with compressed air. Make sure the parts are completely dry before you reassemble them. Attaching parts when they are still wet can result in rust and damage to your saw. Remove the air filter and wash it with warm soapy water. If it is particularly dirty, you can soak it in soapy water and then scrub it with a gentle brush. If you are unable to get it completely clean you should replace the filter. You should regularly check your air filter and clean it as needed to avoid problems like excessive fuel consumption and extreme wear on engine parts. Never use compressed air to clean the air filter as you could blast a hole in it and damage it permanently. You can find replacement chainsaw filters at your local hardware department store or chainsaw dealer.
